description: Borrowed from French annexe, from Latin annexus.

entries.meaning: An appendix to a book or document.
An addition or extension to a building.
An addition to the territory of a country or state, from a neighbouring country or state, normally by military force.

description: From Middle English annexen, anexen, from Old French annexer (“to join”), from Medieval Latin annexāre, infinitive of annexō, frequentative of Latin annectō (“bind to”), from ad (“to”) + nectō (“tie, bind”).

verbs.description: annex (third-person singular simple present annexes, present participle annexing, simple past and past participle annexed)

entries.meaning: To add something to another thing, especially territory; to incorporate.
examples: The ancient city of Petra was annexed by Rome.

entries.meaning: To attach or connect, as a consequence, condition, etc.
examples: Under Edward the Second, the Commons began to annex petitions to the bills by which they granted subsidies
